title: Global climate protests: Activists pour fake blood on famous Wall Street bull
text:
CLOSE

BERLIN – Activists in support of Extinction Rebellion launched an international climate protest Monday, and demonstrations shut down roads in major European cities.

Protesters doused New York City’s famous charging bull statue with fake blood as part of a protest against climate change.

The group Extinction Rebellion staged the protest Monday at the bull statue near Wall Street at the foot of Broadway. One protester waving a green flag climbed on top of the bull.

Environmental activists rally for action against climate change around the Wall Street Bull in the Financial District October 7, 2019 in New York City. (Photo: Drew Angerer, Getty Images)

Financial sectors profit from ecocide, so we must rebel #ExtinctionRebellion#EverybodyNowpic.twitter.com/zcataY6RpP — Extinction Rebellion NYC 🌎 (@XR_NYC) October 7, 2019

Hundreds of activists blocked a central square in Paris. Some of the protesters locked arms and chained themselves together, refusing to move. Others sat on the ground.

The Paris event brought the area around Châtelet to a standstill.

Dutch police detained about 90 demonstrators blocking a busy Amsterdam street.

Police said in a tweet Monday afternoon that the protesters were detained near the Dutch capital’s Rijksmuseum, where the blockade had hindered traffic since early morning.

The demonstration has been peaceful, although singing activists linked arms and lay on the ground to hinder police efforts to remove them from the road.

Protester Elle van Zeeland told Dutch broadcaster NOS that the group is “staying here until the government meets its obligations.”

London police arrested about 135 climate activists.

Demonstrators playing steel drums marched through central London, kicking off two weeks of activities designed to disrupt the city.

Climate activists pose for the media outside Buckingham Palace during an Extinction Rebellion protest in London on Oct. 7, 2019. (Photo: Alberto Pezzali, AP)

Extinction Rebellion said protesters were arrested as they blocked Victoria Embankment outside the Ministry of Defense.

Among those arrested was Sarah Lasenby, 81, a retired social worker from Oxford.

“It is imperative the government should take serious actions and put pressure on other states and global powers to radically reduce the use of fossil fuels,” she said.

Climate activists blocked roads and staged a sit-in in Madrid.

A few dozen activists briefly chained themselves to each other and to an elevated road over a major artery in the Spanish capital at rush hour Monday morning.

Police arrested three activists for resisting orders by anti-riot officers.

A few hundred protesters camped out in 40 tents at the gates of the Spanish Ministry of Ecological Transition.

Extinction Rebellion wants to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2025.

A protester decries climate change outside Britain's Parliament in central London on Oct. 7. (Photo: Matt Dunham, AP)

In April, members of the group blocked several London roads and bridges during 10 days of action designed to alert the public and politicians to the “climate emergency.”

Climate activists blocked a central junction in Berlin.

Police officers carry away an activist for the global environment movement Extinction Rebellion XR as they blocked the 'Potsdamer Platz' crossroads in Berlin, on October 7, 2019. (Photo: Clemens Bilan, EPA-EFE)

About 1,000 people blocked the Grosser Stern, a traffic circle in the middle of the German capital’s Tiergarten park dominated by the landmark Victory Column.

Members of Extinction Rebellion set up a camp outside Chancellor Angela Merkel’s office.

Founded in Britain last year, the movement, also known as XR, has chapters in about 50 countries.

Contributing: Jay Cannon, USA TODAY
